title: The Swan: Remembering the controversial plastic surgery reality series
text:
The Swan aimed to give contestants full makeovers (Picture: YouTube)

Reality TV shows are never without controversy. Love Island sparked concerns over the psychological strain put on contestants. Big Brother received complaints over bullying and racism. I’m A Celebrity… Get Me Out Of Here! has been accused of animal cruelty.

But back in the early noughties, there was one reality series that attracted almost universal backlash and was named Entertainment Weekly’s worst reality series ever.

That show was The Swan – a reality show that somehow ran for two seasons in 2004. US network Fox premiered The Swan in April that year, with 16 women all hoping to make it to the grand pageant final. And how would they get there?

By undergoing a complete plastic surgery overhaul.

As explained in the show’s voiceover: ‘A group of ordinary women hand over their lives to a team of cosmetic and plastic surgeons. They will be put through a brutal three month makeover all for the chance to become beauty queens. Each week, two contestants will be transformed, but only will be judged beautiful enough to move on to the pageant.’

Advertisement

Presented by Irish host Amanda Byram, The Swan – so-called based on the fairytale The Ugly Duckling – chose a cast of women deemed to be unattractive and suffering from low self-esteem and gave them extreme makeovers, not just with a box of hair dye and a make-up artist, but with specially selected plastic surgeons.

The doctors included Dr Randal Haworth and Dr Terry Dubrow, who are both board certified by the American Board of Plastic Surgery – you’ll recognise Dr Dubrow from going on to star on E!’s Botched.

Heartbreaking clips of each woman were shown on the show as they discussed their lack of self-worth and self-esteem, with season two contestant Marsha Meddleburg saying: ‘I feel completely unbearably disgusted with myself. My biggest fear is being alone. I’d give anything to not want to be invisible.’ Season one’s eventual winner Rachel Love-Frazier cried as she said: ‘When you’re a person who doesn’t have a great deal of self-esteem, sometimes you feel like why do I bother.’

Each contestant was reviewed by the panel, including surgeons, a personal trainer, a cosmetic dentist and therapist Dr Lynn Ianni, who attempted to get to the bottom of what was going on inside. Critics of the show noted that Dr Ianni’s PhD in Clinical Psychology came from an online accreditation program.

After Rachel’s raw introduction video, the surgeons decided that she needed an eye lift, liposuction, breast lift, nose job, lip enhancement, chin implants, endobrow lift and veneers, while a trainer prescribed a 1,200 calorie diet and two cardio sessions a day.

Rachel was given a nose job, lip enhancement and chin implants (Picture: YouTube)

Dr Terry Dubrow said: ‘I think she’s a difficult physical transformation. What do you want to do with that nose?’

Advertisement

Advertisement

Dr Ianni pledged to delve into the insecurity transferred to her by her husband and father – with Rachel’s husband Mike saying in a VT: ‘She’s a little average. But when she’s happy she’s a very beautiful person.’

A writer for the show Rebecca Hertz later told Entertainment Weekly: ‘In a pre-interview, I led her husband to say Rachel looks average, but he thought she looked beautiful.

‘I cut it down to him saying she looks average, so he sounded like a mean, horrible a**hole. He was furious when he saw the show.’ (Rachel and Mike later divorced, much like many of the other couples featured on the show.)

After the three-month period, in which they underwent gruelling, invasive surgeries rendering them unrecognisable and ’emotional transformations’, the women were debuted to the team in a glamorous reveal, with the doctors and show hosts fawning over them as they entered a ballroom.

Each women – who had been banned from looking in the mirror for their journey – pulled back a curtain to look in the mirror for the first time, to see their transformation from ‘ugly duckling’ to a ‘swan’. The women usually reacted tearfully, commenting on how beautiful they were now their entire appearance has been changed.

Each week, one contestant was eliminated, leaving room for eight of them to compete in a pageant at the end of the series, consisting of an evening gown round, swimsuit round, lingerie round and a Q&A, to decide who was the winner of The Swan.

Advertisement

The show was cancelled after two series, both of which aired in the same year, but the first series pulled in 9.1 million viewers on average. Pretty good for a show that was universally abhorred by critics – although perhaps the phrase ‘all publicity is good publicity’ came good in this instance.

In her book Reality Bites Back, Jennifer Pozner called The Swan ‘the most sadistic reality series of the decade’, while the show gained a resurgence of hatred and international attention in 2009 and 2010 when it aired for the first time on Channel 4 – with Charlie Brooker discussing The Swan on his show You Have Been Watching.

Many contestants on the show have spoken out against it – most notably season one contestant Lorrie Arias, who was 34 when she went on the series and was given a tummy tuck, buttock lift, inner thigh lift, dual facelift, upper lip lift, upper and lower eye lift, endoscopic brow lift, rhinoplasty, breast augmentation and breast lift, the most procedures of any swan.

In 2010, Lorrie – who had lost 150 pounds herself in 1995- said she regained all the weight she lost in the aftermath of the series, and that she was depressed, bipolar, agoraphobic and suffering from body dysmorphic disorder.

The swans were allowed to see the new them after three months (Picture: YouTube)

She told the New York Post: ‘I am agoraphobic, on meds and unable to enjoy life.’

Alleging that there was no aftercare from the show, she added: ‘“I had the most surgeries of any Swan in the history of the show and it has all gone to absolute s***. I am a 300-pound mess of a person who is afraid to go outside.’

Advertisement

However, not everybody on the show was as negative, with Rachel Love saying: ‘Some of the girls have had problems with their surgeries, and I would have thought [the producers] would have helped a little more with that. But what can you expect from them?

‘Reality shows aren’t there to guide you for the rest of your life.’

And the show’s creator Nely Galan defended The Swan – claiming getting a nip tuck is the same as getting your car a new paint job.

‘People in America spend a lot of money,’ she told the New York Post.

Caroline will host The Surjury (Picture: Channel 4)

‘If your wall in your house is falling apart and chipping, you fix it. If your car is messed up, you get a new paint job. Why would you walk around, after having three kids, with a stomach or boobs that are bothering you, when you can fix them?’

Considering how bad The Swan was when it was on, it’s remarkable that it has aged even worse. So it’s no surprise that people are rather baffled that the series has seemingly been reincarnated in the form of The Surjury.

Channel 4 has confirmed that Caroline Flack will present the new show, which will see people who want plastic surgery pitching their stories and requests to a group of strangers.

The jury will then decide who is granted their wishes to go under the knife.

Channel 4 defended the premise amidst the controversy, saying: ‘Rather than wag a disapproving finger, this new series looks at who wants it, and why – and allows those who make a strong enough case to their peers, to undergo the procedure of their choice.

‘The show will neither glamorise nor condemn their choices: the aim is instead to interrogate the realities. All contributors featured in the series have actively been seeking surgery of their own accord.’

Flack has also defended the series in a row with Jameela Jamil, noting that nobody has watched it yet – although one cosmetic doctor asked to be on the series told Metro.co.uk why he turned it down.

‘I got approached ages ago to do the show and I was pitched an idea from their team about what potentially the programme could be’, he explained.

‘My initial understanding was that the people involved would be ones who were already thinking about getting surgery and then they would talk about why they wanted it done to a studio audience.’

However, when a press release was sent out, Dr Esho raised some concerns and realised it wouldn’t be ethical to take part. ‘I tried to get more information about the show and in the end, I couldn’t get any more so it got to the point where I told my management that I couldn’t do it.

‘I had to look at it from an ethical point of view and to be responsible for the millennial generation.’

None of us have seen The Surjury, expected to air in 2020, so it remains to be seen whether it will be different to the dangerous and exploitative premise that many are imagining. However, in The Swan, we’ve already seen how a show offering people a life transformation via plastic surgery can go.
